awd_titl_txt: Seventh Annual KUMUNU-ISU Conference in Partial Differential Equations, Dynamical Systems, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to bring together senior and early career researchers, including graduate students and postdoctoral scholars, in the 7th series of the “KUMUNU-ISU Conference on PDEs, Dynamical systems, and Applications". KUMUNU-ISU has historically been organized as an annual regional weekend Meeting alternating between the University of Kansas, the University of Missouri-Columbia, the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and Iowa State University. The 7th KUMUNU-ISU Conference will be held at Iowa State University (ISU) April 22-23, 2023. The goals of this conference are: (i) to provide an opportunity for a diverse group of well-regarded researchers to disseminate their recent results in applied mathematics and partial differential equations (PDE); (ii) to facilitate the interaction and exchange of ideas among all conference participants. This project intends to positively impact the educational and research programs of the participating graduate students, postdocs and early career faculty. In particular, the organizers will make a great effort to encourage the participation of researchers who are female and/or from underrepresented groups in STEM.

This Conference will provide a scientifically profitable platform for showcasing recent developments in: (i) the mathematical and numerical analysis of the PDE’s which govern fluid and fluid-structure interactions; (ii) the qualitative properties of general infinite dimensional dynamical systems; (iii) the analysis of coupled parabolic/hyperbolic evolution equations. This project intends that the KUMUNU-ISU Meeting will facilitate mutually beneficial interaction and possibly forge new research collaborations amongst the participants – senior and junior researchers alike – who might generally not have large opportunity to share their views outside their respective research circles. The Conference website is https://faculty.sites.iastate.edu/peling/7th-kumunu-isu-conference-pde-dynamical-systems-and-applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The PI organized "7th Annual KUMUNU-ISU Conference in PDE, Dynamical Systems and Applications" on April 22-23, 2023 at Iowa State University, Ames-Iowa. This event has been alternated between the Mathematics Departments of the University of Kansas, University of Missouri-Columbia, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, and Iowa State University (since 2019). The Organizing Committee consists of experienced mathematicians in respective areas of PDE, Dynamical Systems and Applications: George Avalos (University of Nebraska-Lincoln), Pelin Guven Geredeli (Clemson University, former faculty at Iowa State University), Mat Johnson (University of Kansas), Yuri Latushkin (University of Missouri-Columbia), Dionyssis Mantzavinos (University of Kansas), Samuel Walsh (University of Missouri-Columbia).

The KUMUNU-ISU Conference (Ames) was a forum to bring together specialists, who work in various areas of partial differential equations (PDEs) and infinite dimensional dynamical systems, with graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and early career young faculty. The PI's main objectives in organizing this event were to (1) provide a scientifically profitable platform which was available to researchers of all stripes, especially graduate students and early career young faculty for disseminating recent developments in fluid/flow structure interactive PDEs; (2) discuss the main challenges, open problems and development of new techniques and treatments about the qualitative/quantitative properties of certain dynamical systems; (3) attract the participation of a substantial number of early career faculty, graduate students and postdocs from the group of reserachers who might not ordinarily have a chance to convey their research to a receptive and interested audience; (4) create an environment for establishing new research connections and collaborations between junior and senior mathematicians who work in PDEs and applications. 

The KUMUNU-ISU Conference (Ames) constituted a diverse body of participants who were female and/or from underrepresented minorities; and more generally who were representatives of groups that historically have had a limited presence in Applied Mathematics.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2023
Modified by: Pelin Guven Geredeli
